title: Conjunctions: Contrast, Reason, Result & Time Connectors
summary: This lesson explains how to use conjunctions (however, although, because, so) and time connectors (before, after, while, when, etc.) correctly in sentences.
content: Conjunctions help connect ideas and show relationships between clauses.
Time connectors help sequence events and show when actions happen.
Different connectors have specific punctuation rules and grammatical structures.
Common mistakes include wrong verb tenses and incorrect punctuation.

examples: We didn't like the hotel. However, we had a good time.
I would like a dog; however, my husband is allergic.
rules.notes: Use at sentence beginning after full stop/semicolon, followed by comma

examples: Although he had a bad leg, he won the game.
I passed the exam, although I hadn't studied.
rules.notes: Can begin or middle sentences. No comma after although.

examples: We canceled because it was raining.
I didn't call because I didn't want to worry you.
We canceled because of the rain.
Shops closed because of the economic situation.
We worked hard all morning, so I'm tired now.
The TV is expensive, so I won't buy it.
Before breakfast, I read.
Before having breakfast, I read.
Before I have breakfast, I read.
After dinner, I smoke.
After having dinner, I smoke.
After I have dinner, I smoke.
rules.notes: For consecutive actions use 'then' or 'after that'

examples: I read while I waited.
As soon as I get home, I'll do homework.
When I arrive, I'll call you.
Once I finish, I'll help you.

tips: Use present (not future) after time connectors
Comma when time connector begins sentence
common_errors: Incorrect: 'When I will arrive' Correct: 'When I arrive'
Incorrect: 'I'll call after I will finish' Correct: 'I'll call after I finish'
Incorrect: 'Although, he was tired' Correct: 'Although he was tired'
Incorrect: 'I was tired so I went to bed' Correct: 'I was tired, so I went to bed'
